Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer correctly interpreted the regulations regarding the education component of a Federal Skilled Worker application
Application_Facts: Applicant possessed three degrees but was awarded only 22 points instead of 25 for education under the Federal Skilled Worker program
Decision_Outcome: Visa officer's decision set aside due to error in law
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the visa officer's decision
Court_Ruling: Decision overturned; case referred back for re-determination by a different officer
Defendant_Behavior: Visa officer applied a conjunctive interpretation of s. 78(2)(f), disregarding the applicant's full academic history
Grounds_for_Claim: Incorrect point allocation for education credentials due to erroneous statutory interpretation
Legal_Standard: Correctness standard for questions of law
Assessment_Factor: Point allocation for foreign education credentials
Applicable_Legislation: Section 73 and Section 78 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Evidence_Used: Applicant's academic transcripts and degree certificates
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 78(2)(f) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Application_Basis: Federal Skilled Worker Program – education credential assessment
Evidence_Assessed: Academic records demonstrating completion of three degrees
Relief_Sought: Reassessment of education points and proper application of immigration regulations
Governing_Rule: Regulations require awarding 25 points if applicant holds multiple degrees meeting criteria, regardless of conjunctive interpretation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: None found in applicant’s submission; deficiency attributed to officer’s interpretation
Decisional_Body: Visa Officer, later reviewed by Federal Court
Harm_Assessment: Unfair denial of points impacting eligibility for permanent residence
Cause_Description: Dispute over point allocation for education credentials in a visa application
Evidence_Handling: Academic documents were properly submitted and authenticated
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 78(2)(f) of IRPR – incorrect application of education point allocation
Misrepresentation_Element: Not applicable – no allegation of misrepresentation
Legal_Provision: Section 73 and Section 78, Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Assessment: Court found evidence sufficient and properly assessed
Decision_Rationale: Visa officer erred in law by applying an unduly restrictive interpretation of the regulation
Decision_Making_Body: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office
